case_name: State of Rajasthan v. M/s Shiv Ratan G. Mohatta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 652 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCivil Appeal No. 652 of 1964,

facts.text: Appeal against Rajasthan High Court judgment dated May 7, 1963 in D.B. Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 157 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 7, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 157 of 1962. C. Kasliwal, Advocate-General for Rajasthan.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer, Jodhpur City, made assessment order dated March 5, 1962 levying sales tax on turnover of Rs. 23,92,252.75 np.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the order of assessment dated March 5, 1962, made by the Sales Tax Officer, Jodhpur City, in so far as it levied sales tax on the turnover of Rs. 23,92,252.75 np. The respondent, M s Shiv Ratan G. Mohatta,

facts.text: Respondent Ms Shiv Ratan G. Mohatta is a partnership firm with head office at Jodhpur.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, M s Shiv Ratan G. Mohatta, which is a partnership firm having its head office at Jodhpur, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, claimed before the Sales Tax Officer that they were number liable to be assessed to sales tax in respect of the above turnover because, firstly, the assessee was number a dealer within s. 2 f  of the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act  Rajasthan Act XXlX of 1954  with respect to this turnover, and secondly, because the sales were in the companyrse if import within Art. 286  1  b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Assessee claimed not liable to sales tax as not a dealer under s. 2(f) of Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, 1954 and sales in course of import under Art. 286(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: claimed before the Sales Tax Officer that they were number liable to be assessed to sales tax in respect of the above turnover because, firstly, the assessee was number a dealer within s. 2 f  of the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act  Rajasthan Act XXlX of 1954  with respect to this turnover, and secondly, because the sales were in the companyrse if import within Art. 286  1  b  of the Constitution. Although the Sales Tax Officer set out the facts of the case relating to the second ground, he deemed it sufficient to assess this turnover on the ground that the assessee was a dealer within s. 2 f  of the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, without adverting to the second ground.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer assessed assessee as dealer under s. 2(f) without addressing course of import claim.

anchor.surface_text: Although the Sales Tax Officer set out the facts of the case relating to the second ground, he deemed it sufficient to assess this turnover on the ground that the assessee was a dealer within s. 2 f  of the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, without adverting to the second ground. The facts on which the assessee had relied upon to substantiate his second ground were these.

facts.text: Zeal-Pak Cement Factory in Hyderabad, Pakistan manufactured cement.

anchor.surface_text: The Zeal-Pak Cement Factory, Hyderabad  Pakistan , hereinafter called the Pakistan Factory, manufactured cement in Pakistan.

facts.text: Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation entered agreement with Ms Milkhiram and Sons P Ltd., Bombay for export of cement to India.

anchor.surface_text: The Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation, hereinafter called the Pakistan Corporation, entered into an agreement with M s Milkhiram and Sons  P  Ltd., Bombay, for the export of cement manufactured in Pakistan to India.

facts.text: State Trading Corporation of India entered agreement with Ms Milkhiram Sons for purchase of 35,000 long tons of cement delivered O.R. Khokhropar in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The State Trading Corporation of India entered into an agreement with the said M s Milkhiram Sons for the purchase of, inter alia, 35,000 long tons of cement to be delivered to it O.R. Khokhropar in Pakistan, on the border of Rajasthan.

facts.text: State Trading Corporation appointed assessee as agent to look after import and sale of imported cement.

anchor.surface_text: The State Trading Corporation appointed the assessee as its agent, broadly speaking, to look after the import and the sale of the imported cement.

facts.text: Assessee obtained orders from buyers in Rajasthan under agreements fixing price and terms, disclaiming responsibility for transit issues.

anchor.surface_text: It would obtain from a buyer in Rajasthan an order under an agreement, a sample of which is on the record The agreement fixed the price and the terms of supply. By one clause the assessee disclaimed any responsibility regarding delay in dispatch and number-receipt of companysignment or any loss, damage or shortage in transit due to any reason whatsoever. The agreement further provided that all claims for loss, damage or shortage, etc., during transit will lie with the carriers and our payments are number to be delayed on any such account whatsoever.

facts.text: Assessee sent despatch instructions to Pakistan Corporation indicating buyer-consignee, destination, and RR to be sent to consignee.

anchor.surface_text: After this agreement had been entered into, the assessee would send despatch instructions to the Pakistan Corporation. These instructions indicated the name of the buyer-consignee and the destination, and provided that the railway receipt and D A should be sent by registered post to the companysignee.

facts.text: Pakistan Factory advised consignee that goods consigned to State Bank of India, Karachi, which endorsed RR to consignee by post.

anchor.surface_text: Later, the Pakistan Factory would advise the companysignee that they had companysigned to the State Bank of India, Karachi, the particular quantity as per enclosed railway receipt and invoice. The State Bank of India, Karachi, would endorse the railway receipt in favour of the companysignee and send it to him by post.

facts.text: Consignee took delivery using railway receipt or indemnity bond.

anchor.surface_text: The companysignee would take delivery either by presentation of the railway receipt or by giving indemnity bond to the Station Master undertaking to deliver the railway receipt on its receipt.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer held assessee was agent of non-resident dealer, importer, liable to pay sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer did set out most of these facts and the companytentions of the assessee in the assessment order but disposed of the case with the following observations All the above went to prove that the assessee was an Agent of the number-resident dealer for the supplies in the State. The Assessee was an importer and hence submitted an application to the Custom Authority for the same. It booked orders and issued sale bills.

facts.text: Assessee filed writ petition under Art. 226 raising failure to consider Art. 286(1)(b) and illegal holding as dealer.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then filed a petition under art. 226 of the Constitution and raised two companytentions before the High Court, namely,  1  that the Sales Tax Officer failed to companysider the impact and the effect of Art. 286 1  b  on the facts of the case, and  2  that the Sales Tax Officer illegally held that the petitioner for all intents and purposes was a dealer liable to pay sales tax.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court quashed assessment order regarding the disputed turnover holding sales in course of import under Art. 286(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court quashed the order of assessment in so far as it sought to levy tax on the turnover in dispute.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer and State of Rajasthan obtained certificate of fitness from High Court and filed appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer, Jodhpur, and the State of Rajasthan having obtained certificate of fitness from the High Court filed this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court should have declined to entertain the writ petition due to alternative remedy.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the High Court should have declined to entertain the petition. No exceptional circumstances exist in this case to warrant the exercise of the extraordinary jurisdiction under Art. 226.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order, quashed assessment order for the turnover, and remitted case to Sales Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly. we allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court, quash the assessment order in so far as it relates to the. turnover of Rs. 23,92.252.75 up, and remit the case to the Sales Tax Officer to decide the case in accordance with law.

arguments.claim: High Court under Art. 226 should not decide factual questions or act as assessing authority in tax matters; remit to STO

anchor.surface_text: The proper order in the circumstances of this case would have been to quash the order of assessment and send the case back to the Sales Tax Officer to dispose of it according to law. Under the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, and other Sales Tax Acts,

holdings.text: The High Court should have declined to entertain the writ petition under Art. 226 as no exceptional circumstances exist to warrant exercise of extraordinary jurisdiction and alternative remedy of appeal was available.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the High Court should have declined to entertain the petition. No exceptional circumstances exist in this case to warrant the exercise of the extraordinary jurisdiction under Art. 226. It was not the object of art. 226 to convert High Courts into original or appellate assessing authorities whenever an assessee chose to attack an assessment order on the ground that a sale was made in the course of import and therefore exempt from tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative statutory remedy available under Rajasthan Sales Tax Act; deposit of tax does not justify bypass unless goes to root of jurisdiction; no exceptional circumstances present.

holdings.text: It is not the function of the High Court under Art. 226 in taxing matters to constitute itself into an original or appellate authority to determine taxability questions involving disputed or missing facts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts to be found by assessing authorities and appellate forums under Sales Tax Act; High Court confined to record; should not encourage bypassing statutory remedies except in exceptional cases.

holdings.text: The Sales Tax Officer failed to deal with or consider the contention under Art. 286(1)(b) regarding sales in course of import.

anchor.surface_text: We can find no discussion in the order on the question raised by the assessee that the sales were made in the course of import within Art. 286 1 b of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessment order set out facts but disposed case solely on dealer status without adverting to Art. 286(1)(b) ground raised by assessee.

holdings.text: Proper course is to quash assessment order for failure to consider relevant contention and remit to Sales Tax Officer for fresh decision on all issues including dealer status and Art. 286(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The proper order in the circumstances of this case would have been to quash the order of assessment and send the case back to the Sales Tax Officer to dispose of it according to law. Under the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, and other Sales Tax Acts, the facts have to be found by the assessing authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court went beyond quashing to decide merits; STO to find facts and reach independent conclusion untrammelled by High Court views.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; assessment quashed insofar as disputed turnover; case remitted to Sales Tax Officer for decision in accordance with law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: To enable STO to address all contentions including s.2(f) and Art.286(1)(b) after finding necessary facts.

precedents.citation: J. V. Gokal and Co. Private Ltd. v. The Assistant Collector of Sales Tax Inspection Others, ,

anchor.surface_text: in course of import. In view of the authority of their Lordships of the Supreme Court in J. V. Gokal and Co. Private Ltd. v. The Assistant Collector of Sales Tax Inspection Others, , it must be taken that the sale took place when the goods were in the course of the import and they should number be liable to the payment of the Sales Tax by virtue of Art. 286 1 b  In the result, the High Court quashed the order of assessment in so far as it sought to levy tax on the turnover in dispute. The Sales Tax Officer, Jodhpur, and the State of Rajasthan having obtained certificate of fitness from the High Court filed this appeal.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sale takes place in the course of import if property passes while goods are in course of import, exempt under Art. 286(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: the High Court should decline to decide such questions. It is true, as said by this Court in A. V. Venkateswarn v. Ramchand Sobharaj Wadhwani 1  that it would number be .desirable to lay down inflexible rules which should be applied with rigidity in every case, but even so when the question of taxability depends upon a precise determination of facts and some of the facts are in dispute or missing, the High Court should decline to decide such questions. precedents.cited_proposition: No inflexible rules should be laid down rigidly for exercising writ jurisdiction in tax matters

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the High Court should have declined to entertain the petition. No exceptional circumstances exist in this case to warrant the exercise of the extraordinary jurisdiction under Art. 226. It was not the object of art. 226 to convert High Courts into original or appellate assessing authorities whenever an assessee chose to attack an assessment order on the ground that a sale was made in the course of import and therefore exempt from tax.

Accordingly. we allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court, quash the assessment order in so far as it relates to the. turnover of Rs. 23,92.252.75 up, and remit the case to the Sales Tax Officer to decide the case in accordance with law. He will

anchor.surface_text: The proper order in the circumstances of this case would have been to quash the order of assessment and send the case back to the Sales Tax Officer to dispose of it according to law. Under the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, and other Sales Tax Acts, the facts have to be found by the assessing authorities.

Accordingly. we allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court, quash the assessment order in so far as it relates to the. turnover of Rs. 23,92.252.75 up, and remit the case to the Sales Tax Officer to decide the case in accordance with law. He will
